messageBody:
Hi David,

Personally, I'd just use multiple tests or two theories - one for
in-bounds and one for out-of bounds indices.

But if one were adamant about having a single test, it's
possible to create an assertThrows that takes a class as
argument, essentially simulating delegates.

Seems like a lot of code to do something so hinky though. :-)

Charlie

> Yosef,
>
> I think I can see what you'd like to do, and I can tell you
> that JUnit does not support it natively. Also, I'm not sure
> exactly what the semantics of that test would be. For
> example, what if s[4] threw an
> ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, but s[5] did not? What if
> none of the array accesses threw a
> ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, but println did?
>
> David Saff
>

> <yosefshariat@...> wrote:
> > Hello
> > I write a unit test where must be Exception.
